Journal.Title: Journal of geophysical research. Atmospheres : JGR

Article.ArticleTitle: Tropospheric ozonesonde profiles at long-term U.S. monitoring sites: 2. Links between Trinidad Head, CA, profile clusters and inland surface ozone measurements.

AbstractText: Much attention has been focused on the transport of ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) to the Western U.S., particularly given the latest revision of the National Ambient Air Quality Standard (NAAQS) to 70 parts per billion by volume (ppbv) of O<sub>3</sub>. This makes defining a "background" O<sub>3</sub> amount essential so that the effects of stratosphere-to-troposphere exchange and pollution transport to this region can be quantified. To evaluate free-tropospheric and surface O<sub>3</sub> in the Western U.S., we use self-organizing maps to cluster 18 years of ozonesonde profiles (940 samples) from Trinidad Head, CA. Two of nine O<sub>3</sub> mixing ratio profile clusters exhibit thin laminae of high O<sub>3</sub> above Trinidad Head. A third, consisting of background (~20 - 40 ppbv) O<sub>3</sub>, occurs in ~10% of profiles. The high O<sub>3</sub> layers are located between 1 and 4 km amsl, and reside above a subsidence inversion associated with a northern location of the semi-permanent Pacific subtropical high. Several ancillary data sets are examined to identify the high O<sub>3</sub> sources (reanalyses, trajectories, remotely-sensed carbon monoxide), but distinguishing chemical and stratospheric influences of the elevated O<sub>3</sub> is difficult. There is marked and long-lasting impact of the elevated tropospheric O<sub>3</sub> on high-altitude surface O<sub>3</sub> monitors at Lassen Volcanic and Yosemite National Parks, and Truckee, CA. Days corresponding to the high O<sub>3</sub> clusters exhibit hourly surface O<sub>3</sub> anomalies of +5 - 10 ppbv compared to a climatology; the anomalies can last up to four days. The profile and surface O<sub>3</sub> links demonstrate the importance of regular ozonesonde profiling at Trinidad Head.
